headline: 'The Five' on Biden's failing energy policies

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everybody, I'm Jesse Watters along with Dagen McDowell, Geraldo Rivera, Dana Perino and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5:00 in New York City and this is "The Five." President Biden is proving he's totally clueless and Americans aren't having it anymore. Joe Biden turning a blind eye to the problems plaguing the country including rising gas prices, massive inflation and energy crisis all being made worse by his policies.  The White House now playing cleanup after getting called out over a plan to shut down the pipeline in Michigan. It now says it's only reviewing, building a new one. And when it comes to the pain at the pump, the White House basically telling Americans, too bad, just deal with it.

utterances.speaker: KARINE JEAN-PIERRE, WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: We're very concerned about the impact of high energy prices on consumers especially as we enter the colder months. We just don't have anything right now to announce, but like I said we're monitoring this and we're working through what is it and how we can actually address this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The Republican lawmaker, Jim Jordan, torching Biden over the higher prices saying this is all by design.

utterances.speaker: REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH)
utterances.sentences: What do these guys want, $8 gas? He had the big oil company executives in there from Chevron, Exxon, BP, you had them in there, and Ro Khanna was badgering these guys saying will you commit to reducing production? So Joe Biden begs OPEC to increase production and Democrat members of Congress badger American companies to decrease production. I mean, this makes no sense.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And Americans are losing faith in Biden fast. A new poll shows that over half say Biden hasn't even been focusing on issues that actually matter. Greg, you brought this up the other day. This is by design, the higher prices. I think it was you, someone that looked like you.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's worth reminding people this is what Joe Biden said about phasing out fossil fuels. Run it.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.sentences: We're going to get rid of fossil fuels. They want to do the same thing I want to do. They want to phase out fossil fuels and we're going to phase out fossil fuels.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You think this is part of the plan?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think if you have a less independent population due to an economic crisis, they are more dependent on the government. We even saw that with COVID. The free money was kind of an accelerated version of that. I know that it's 5:00 so I need to get permission to be disgusting.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I never really ask for permission but I figured I would now and the producers probably aren't even listening, right? They're probably just getting their coffee and so they have no idea. So what Joe is saying is he doesn't want you to pay attention to what's going on. He's always passing the buck, right? He's not taking responsibility but we had a saying back in third grade, you know what that was? Whoever smelled it dealt it.  It may be silent, but it's deadly. He's the guy that always lets one fly in an elevator and then assumes if nobody else -- if he doesn't react, no one else will react either, even though the stench of his White House is overpowering. He releases more gas than OPEC. Maybe that's why he doesn't think we need more energy.  But the big thing is you see MSNBC saying inflation is a good thing, CNN saying, oh, Joe can't do much about this. It's out of his hands. It's unusual and weird to see the media say, what can you do about stuff, when they spend so much time saying you must do something. Whether it's climate, you must do something. Whether it's gun control, you must do something. But here it is. People have to pay more for food, gas and oil. It's like, not so fast. It's really not on him. And I think that goes back to what I said, that they want a society that's more dependent on government and that's why this is not that big of a deal.  I wish Joe was doing nothing but like you said in the opening, he's actively destroying our energy sector. As gasoline prices soar cutting off pipelines, that's like basically removing, you know, your children's playground set as the kid gains weight. This is not helpful.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's funny. You're right. The Democrats have finally found the one thing they can't control.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Energy production.

utterances.speaker: GERALDO RIVERA, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: I thought you're going to say farting in elevators.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Would you like -- I was going to go to Dana. Why don't I move over to Geraldo and let me follow up on that analogy.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: How do you pay attention to his pretty intellectual discourse after he starts it with flatulence?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, that's what grabs your attention and then you pay more attention.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's a combination of the two.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The hook. The hook. This gnarly hook.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Your thoughts on what we're seeing right now with this administration?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I think its most -- I think Afghanistan is very instructive because in Afghanistan they had good intentions and they did it ass backwards. Instead of evacuating the civilians first, they evacuated the military. Civilians stuck. They had to redo.  And I think the same thing is happening with fossil fuels. They want to eliminate fossil fuels. They cut down on the supply of fossil fuels. In furtherance of that goal way before the alternative has been developed.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. It's not ready.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: So it's, again, it's ass backwards. First you develop. First, you want everyone to have Tesla, then you can get rid of fossil fuels. To do it now when it drives up prices at the pump I think that that is problematic and I think that that is very instructive of his thought process and how they are reacting almost in knee jerk fashion to whatever it is. It's very improvisational and I find it distressing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Ass backwards, Dagen.

utterances.speaker: DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm all for that, usually. The fact that Biden and his liberal cadre, in the past, they have been so slavish to the polls and so reactionary. Remember last in the summer of 2020 when the polls started moving against him, all the rioting, both Harris and Biden came out in August and said, oh, we denounce violence, even though it had been going on for weeks, a couple of months at least. But now they don't seem to care about the polls.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Good point.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Which is hugely troubling and frightening. So, what they see is they are going to ignore the polls and they see this -- even ignore the election, the losses in Virginia, because they see this window closing now.   They've got one year to push through this incredibly divisive but left wing agenda. This scary ass worldview that imposes -- they are imposing their will on the country whether it's forcing people through higher prices to use alternative energy. They are going to spend $4 trillion more to create this giant new century welfare monstrosity.  It's all about not just bigger government but more centralized government. Europe on steroids and certainly more power to those in power already. A scorched earth approach to getting their way. And I'll just point to last month, and it's not just necessarily at the federal level. Gretchen Whitmer tried to, last year, shut down this -- it's a 4 1/2-mile stretch of this line 5 pipeline. It is a -- she was trying to terminate this easement. And Canada last month had to invoke a treaty to stop it. This sends fuel not just into the United States, but fuel to heat and gas up the cars in Ontario and Quebec. They hate Canada.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, and they were supposed to be very diplomatic compared to the previous president, they claim. So, that's a great point. They were very nimble when it came to the polling, at least acting like they cared about public sentiment and the election and now they are just like, go walk.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You've seen this on many issues. One of them was Afghanistan. Remember, their solution on Afghanistan was to say, well, this is the largest airlift in history and also everyone will forget about this in a month.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Spin.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That didn't happen. They are doing this on immigration. They are in the teens in immigration in the polling and they are sort of like, yes, we're not doing anything on that. And then the midterm ads write themselves because basically what they've done is a, we're not going to pay attention to the things you care about even though people are saying, these are the things we care about and they still ignore them.   And there is -- today they are pushing this $500 billion for climate change issues while people are actually talking about the high price of gas and groceries. And then they have this grab bag of policies, and it's like if your mom gave you $20 and said go to the store and get some groceries for the family and you go and you get two six packs of beer and some magazines, you come home and say, no, the family is still hungry.  And what the deputy press secretary said today was that we have no specifics on that. And they won't. And this is a story that's not going to go away like in Afghanistan. It's not on the front pages, but it's still on people's minds. Winter is just beginning. And so you got a long way ahead. Granholm just said, 54 percent increase for your heating oil costs. You think that's not going to reverberate through the whole country? And also it takes a while for supply and demand to work itself out on energy issues and they are not doing anything to increase supply except for asking OPEC to help. That's a bad position to be in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Two six packs and a couple of magazines. That's my Thanksgiving. It's affordable. You know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But you'll still be hungry.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And your family is upset.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Global warming might bail them out with energy shortages.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Everything is racist according to the Biden administration. Even roads. That's next on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: The Biden administration is laser focused on the issues affecting every day Americans like how roads are racist. Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg says the new infrastructure bill will address that.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Can you give us the construct of how you will deconstruct the racism that was built into the roadways that you talked to theGrio earlier?

utterances.speaker: PETE BUTTIGIEG, TRANSPORTATION SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: I'm still surprised that some people were surprised when I pointed to the fact that if a highway was built for the purpose of dividing a white and a black neighborhood, or if an underpass was constructed such that a bus carrying mostly black and Puerto Rican kids to a beach -- or that would have been -- in New York was designed too low for it to pass by, but that obviously reflects racism that went into those design choices.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Trees can apparently be racist. Vice President Kamala Harris asking NASA about it.

utterances.speaker: KAMAL HARRIS, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.sentences: Can you measure trees, as part of the data that you're referring to, and it's an E.J., it's environmental justice but you can also track by race, there are averages in terms of the number of trees in the neighborhood where people live.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Racist! Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, I've got to say Mayor Pete looks great. Clearly he's lost the baby weight. This is the problem with the "everything is racist prism" because you can apply it to everything and it's very seductive because it makes the user seem educated and clever when it's merely kind of repeating something that you already heard.   He just heard those stories so he repeats it and it comes out as, wow, this is really interesting, but it's actually not an original thought, but it's an acceptable thought at cocktail parties. The problem with this, how does his policy or the policy based on this affect the actual outcome?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Like, where are you going to change the bridges or the streets? What if the changes are actually really good for everybody? Like what if the improvements on this racist, you know, bridge actually is beneficial? Why did you have to bring this up? But if you don't have a specific solution for this, but you brought it up anyway, then it's a pretty obvious virtue signal to appear thoughtful and progressive and woke, but I just -- I'm interested to see when this was all done, where they are going to point to and go, see, this was the bridge I was talking about.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Cross Bronx Expressway. I could point to it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So what are you going to do with it?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The question is, you don't use this money for social engineering. I mean, that's the problem. That's what's disappointing to me. Eisenhower's interstate system was the grandest, greatest, public works project there was since the Erie Canal. It opened up America for everybody. It benefitted everybody. Rich people, poor people, black people, white people, Asian people, Hispanic people. Everybody benefited. If we start with Pete Buttigieg leading the way to point at these projects like to change the bridge over the Cross Bronx Expressway which works fine now, people have adjusted, instead of building new bridges or repairing the bridges that exist and tunnels and roadways and making Wi-Fi available for everybody.  And it's going to be in the hands of the same racially oriented politicians that we used to call poverty pimps when I was the lawyer for the Young Lords. Poverty pimps. They work. They jockey these programs. They find out what's happening. If you make this a social program, a social welfare program, which is what "Build Back Better" is supposed to be, but if you make infrastructure, social welfare, what you're going to get is nothing. At the end of the line you're going to have that money squandered.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: I have a theory about why Buttigieg would be talking about this now, but it's to Greg's point. Any time you, like talk about racism and call someone or a group of people racist you're trying to get them scared and to back off and to kind of butt out. And to Dana, I wonder -- to Geraldo's point, it's because they want power and control over that money and they don't want anybody to ask any questions. It's not going to get built on, taking down overpasses. It's going to get built on things that aren't roads, bridges and actual infrastructure.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, also it says its a billion dollars to remedy, so what's the remedy, right? And that could also be said about the tree issue and tree equity. I understand what you're saying, like more trees in a place is a good thing. And if you look at a place like, I believe its Greenville, South Carolina. Twenty-five years ago there was a big push to put trees down the main street and there was a big controversy. It was going to cost too much money. Now, it's lovely because the trees are built -- the trees have grown up. It's shady. It's a beautiful street to shop along. It benefits everyone. And I think what the voters were saying last Tuesday is that we can support things that support everybody but we don't want to be put in these different categories. We might need to right some wrongs in the past, but then again, the remedy, as they say here, is going to actually benefit everyone because we don't have that society like we used to have.

utterances.speaker: MCDOEWLL
utterances.sentences: Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I did a deep dive on this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No you didn't.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Deep even for me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And what I found out that, yes, race was a factor in some of the design of the interstate highway system, granted. But class was a much bigger factor. Poor white and black neighborhoods were carved up by this highway system because it's much easier to seize a poor neighborhood through eminent domain. You put the artery into the downtown shopping district and the artery out to the suburbs for the commuters and that's how it's done. They went into German, Italian, Jewish neighborhoods, all white people, and they just carved them out.  How many times have you heard the phrase "this poor white neighborhood" on the wrong side of the tracks? It's always a wrong side of the tracks. It is not black, it's not white. It's about rich and poor. And that's how they did this. So, just because we have to fix a part of the system doesn't mean the system was racist. It just means some of it was designed by idiots. Most of the problems we have in this country is because of idiots, not because of racists. And what the idiots are doing in the Biden administration is they're saying we're going to start destroying highways and we're going to replace these highways with mass transit. We don't want mass transit. Mass transit has been on the decline for the last 15 years. We just came out of a pandemic where people are leaving cities. People are working remotely. The last thing we need are more trains and subways and buses. So they are just going to jam this down our throat. And what's going to happen, the Big Dig. Remember Boston? They tried to rip up their whole highway system and it took 25 years and the cost was five times as bad, and it just created more drama and more, I don't know, congestion, which creates more emissions. So you're going to now see a boondoggle ala the Big Dig in every single city and in every single place where this Build Back Better money is going to go and you're just going to look back and say, Jesse Watters was right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We do that all the time.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You came right to my mind. Always got that, damn, that Jesse was right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Always right.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Always looking for the opportunity to use word the boondoggle.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Boondoggle. I love -- billion dollar boondoggle.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Say it with Buttigieg.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's his.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: It's actually --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He looks great by the way.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, he really does.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He really has lost a lot of baby weight.

utterances.speaker: GUTELD
utterances.sentences: You know, what a bounce back. Usually it takes months, but you know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think he was on the treadmill.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He got the one treadmill they couldn't get.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The one peloton.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: I was about to make a joke, and I am editing myself because it would get me in so much trouble, Dana Perino. Ahead on "The Five," Democrats not learning their lesson. They can't stop smearing parents.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Ignore those school board moms at your peril. Like it or lump it, Democrats and the media still not getting the message over why they got their butts kicked in Virginia. Republican Senator Rick Scott calling out CNN over why parents revolted in the old dominion.

utterances.speaker: BRIANNA KEILAR, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: It's not in the curriculum in Virginia. Just to be --

utterances.speaker: SEN. RICK SCOTT (R-FL)
utterances.sentences: Brianna (inaudible) here. Let me just read you a few things.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Just to --

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.sentences: In 2015, look, Terry McAuliffe was governor. The Virginia Department of Education promoting incorporating a critical race theory lens in education. You can still find it on the Department of Education's website. Still there. In February of 2019 --

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: It's not -- it's not part of the --

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.sentences: -- a superintendent memo from the Virginia Department of Education promoting critical race theory --

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Senator, it's not --

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.sentences: -- and the idea of white fragility. I hope Democrats continue to say it's not happening because parents are dumb. They can see it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: They look so unhappy on CNN.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, they are because they are.

utterances.speaker: RIUVERA
utterances.sentences: And yet DNC Chair Jamie Harrison still doubling down on the notion that racism was behind the Republican victories.

utterances.speaker: JAMIE HARRISON, DNC CHAIRMAN
utterances.sentences: They understand that the only (inaudible) power for them is to make the American people scared. To come up with all of the dog whistles and the boogeymen and all of that. Democrats have to call out the lies and we have to be bold and calling them out and we've got to make sure that we paint the contract. Let people know what we have done for them.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And why I think he's right about that, Democrats if they have achievements should be promoting their achievements, Dagen, but as a resident of -- as someone who hails from the old dominion, don't you think race is relevant for children growing up in Virginia because Virginia was like the heart and soul of the slave economy.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: History is taught. History should be taught. That's not what critical race theory is about and it's not the problem that parents and Virginians had when they went to the polls and elected a Republican governor and a Republican lieutenant governor or the first black woman ever elected to statewide office, and a Republican attorney general. I mean, I could sit here for days and go over what is being taught in the Virginia schools that they take issue with. It's derived from say, the ideas in Albemarle County, from Ibram Kendi, author of "How to Be an Anti- Racist," children being taught words like cisgender, white privilege, non- Christian folks with an X. And like issues of gender, race, sexuality, things that parent feel like should be up to them. I digress. But I love watching Brianna Keilar or whatever her name is, belching up what her liberal overlords have told her to regurgitate. It's got to burn. I love how they will take parents are delusional wackos and then Trump and Russia collusion and they say something real is made up and then say something made up is real. That's the world in which they live. It is -- they are evangelists of left wing moronicy.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: But you can't ignore, race matters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, the race does matter and that's what the parents were saying. We don't like being taught reverse racism. We don't our students, our children being called born racist in elementary school. I want to talk about Brianna.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't like to do this because I don't like to ever mention these people by name. I feel like I want to be loved and I don't ever want to see these people at bars and have their wives or their husbands throw haymakers at me.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: We love you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't like to punch down like Gutfeld. I don't want to, you know, elevate the competition, but I think --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I can only punch up at my height.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think we need to address Brianna. Maybe she's nice. Maybe we get along if we met each other, but she is on a network that says facts first, and she at this point doesn't know that CRT is embedded in the curriculum of the Virginia school system? At this point she doesn't know this? The story has been percolating since April and she doesn't know that. I mean, does she now also think the dossier was real? Does she think the Youngkin supporters were the ones with the tiki torches? Does she think, Geraldo --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- that those two brothers actually did knock around Jussie Smollett that night in Chicago? Because I don't know if her producers are not giving her the right information. If I were Brianna, I would blame the producers too. That's what I do. But this is why our show's so much better than that show. So many reasons, here's one. We get these research packets in the morning and they have facts in the packets, Brianna. And they also have articles from the left and the right so you know what the left is saying about an issue, you know what the right saying about an issue, you know what the media is saying about an issue. And then we as hosts do our own research and we look for the truth and then we formulate our opinions based on that truth. So, there's truth out there. It's on the internet. She could look that up anywhere she wants. And if I ever make a mistake on the air, I will go about and correct it. And that's a few times I've been challenged and then in the commercial break I say, maybe I'm wrong here, nope not wrong. And then the other person has to correct the record. For instance, the other day, I said erroneously that the staff was not trendy. And I immediately corrected the record and I think Brianna should do the same.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The staff was not trending?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes -- trendy.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Oh, trendy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I gave them my shirt.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, they're so trendy now.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Doesn't it remind you -- Dana, isn't it parallel to the old teaching sex ed to third graders and fourth graders. I mean parents are edgy generally speaking.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't remember that.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Well, you're younger.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't remember that but it could be.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You don't remember? They don't want like graphics, sex --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It could be. We'll check it out at the commercial break and figure --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- this is the boys --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think a lot of this also has to do with many people who are commenting about this and saying it has nothing to do with these schools. They don't have school-age children. And if you look at the exit polls in Virginia, parents of school-aged children K-12 went for Youngkin by a huge margin. And so, they have taken on parents and they've made them mad. And -- but the parents were not just mad about the CRT thing. They're mad that the schools were closed for so long, that there was a major loss of learning, that they don't even have the opportunity to have gifted and talented programs and advanced math. When Youngkin says I will make sure that every high school has advanced math and he gets applause, that's when you know parents are really paying attention. And they're making a mistake not doing the same.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Do you really believe in your heart of hearts, Greg, that it isn't a signal -- Dana talks of virtue signaling. Isn't there race signaling also? When you look at some of the rural counties in Virginia that went for Youngkin by 80 percent, 80 to 20, isn't there something about -- isn't race relevant to that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Not in this --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Weren't some white suburban --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wait, what?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

The irony and the best part about this is when you hear proponents of CRT try to define it, and you hear critics try to define it, the definition is entirely the same. That's what kills me. They're not disagreeing. Identify children by their race within a country riven with systemic racism with the conclusion that White is the oppressor, right, and Black is the victim. If you say that, the proponents will go, that's pretty good. You got it. And the critics will go, you're absolutely right. That's exactly what they're saying. So, they're in agreement here. That's the funniest part about this. And it is dead because the parents finally woke up to this and found out that this was dangerous. utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Americans are losing faith in Biden fast. A new poll shows that over half say Biden hasn't even been focusing on issues that actually matter. Greg, you brought this up the other day. This is by design, the higher prices. I think it was you, someone that looked like you.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's worth reminding people this is what Joe Biden said about phasing out fossil fuels. Run it.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: We're going to get rid of fossil fuels. They want to do the same thing I want to do. They want to phase out fossil fuels and we're going to phase out fossil fuels.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You think this is part of the plan?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I think if you have a less independent population due to an economic crisis, they are more dependent on the government. We even saw that with COVID. The free money was kind of an accelerated version of that. I know that it's 5:00 so I need to get permission to be disgusting.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I never really ask for permission but I figured I would now and the producers probably aren't even listening, right? They're probably just getting their coffee and so they have no idea. So what Joe is saying is he doesn't want you to pay attention to what's going on. He's always passing the buck, right? He's not taking responsibility but we had a saying back in third grade, you know what that was? Whoever smelled it dealt it. It may be silent, but it's deadly. He's the guy that always lets one fly in an elevator and then assumes if nobody else -- if he doesn't react, no one else will react either, even though the stench of his White House is overpowering. He releases more gas than OPEC. Maybe that's why he doesn't think we need more energy. But the big thing is you see MSNBC saying inflation is a good thing, CNN saying, oh, Joe can't do much about this. It's out of his hands. It's unusual and weird to see the media say, what can you do about stuff, when they spend so much time saying you must do something. Whether it's climate, you must do something. Whether it's gun control, you must do something. But here it is. People have to pay more for food, gas and oil. It's like, not so fast. It's really not on him. And I think that goes back to what I said, that they want a society that's more dependent on government and that's why this is not that big of a deal. I wish Joe was doing nothing but like you said in the opening, he's actively destroying our energy sector. As gasoline prices soar cutting off pipelines, that's like basically removing, you know, your children's playground set as the kid gains weight. This is not helpful.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's funny. You're right. The Democrats have finally found the one thing they can't control.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Energy production.

utterances.speaker: GERALDO RIVERA, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: I thought you're going to say farting in elevators.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Would you like -- I was going to go to Dana. Why don't I move over to Geraldo and let me follow up on that analogy.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: How do you pay attention to his pretty intellectual discourse after he starts it with flatulence?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, that's what grabs your attention and then you pay more attention.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a combination of the two.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The hook. The hook. This gnarly hook.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Your thoughts on what we're seeing right now with this administration?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I think its most -- I think Afghanistan is very instructive because in Afghanistan they had good intentions and they did it ass backwards. Instead of evacuating the civilians first, they evacuated the military. Civilians stuck. They had to redo. And I think the same thing is happening with fossil fuels. They want to eliminate fossil fuels. They cut down on the supply of fossil fuels. In furtherance of that goal way before the alternative has been developed.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. It's not ready.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: So it's, again, it's ass backwards. First you develop. First, you want everyone to have Tesla, then you can get rid of fossil fuels. To do it now when it drives up prices at the pump I think that that is problematic and I think that that is very instructive of his thought process and how they are reacting almost in knee jerk fashion to whatever it is. It's very improvisational and I find it distressing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ass backwards, Dagen.

utterances.speaker: DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'm all for that, usually. The fact that Biden and his liberal cadre, in the past, they have been so slavish to the polls and so reactionary. Remember last in the summer of 2020 when the polls started moving against him, all the rioting, both Harris and Biden came out in August and said, oh, we denounce violence, even though it had been going on for weeks, a couple of months at least. But now they don't seem to care about the polls.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Good point.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Which is hugely troubling and frightening. So, what they see is they are going to ignore the polls and they see this -- even ignore the election, the losses in Virginia, because they see this window closing now. They've got one year to push through this incredibly divisive but left wing agenda. This scary ass worldview that imposes -- they are imposing their will on the country whether it's forcing people through higher prices to use alternative energy. They are going to spend $4 trillion more to create this giant new century welfare monstrosity. It's all about not just bigger government but more centralized government. Europe on steroids and certainly more power to those in power already. A scorched earth approach to getting their way. And I'll just point to last month, and it's not just necessarily at the federal level. Gretchen Whitmer tried to, last year, shut down this -- it's a 4 1/2-mile stretch of this line 5 pipeline. It is a -- she was trying to terminate this easement. And Canada last month had to invoke a treaty to stop it. This sends fuel not just into the United States, but fuel to heat and gas up the cars in Ontario and Quebec. They hate Canada.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, and they were supposed to be very diplomatic compared to the previous president, they claim. So, that's a great point. They were very nimble when it came to the polling, at least acting like they cared about public sentiment and the election and now they are just like, go walk.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You've seen this on many issues. One of them was Afghanistan. Remember, their solution on Afghanistan was to say, well, this is the largest airlift in history and also everyone will forget about this in a month.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Spin.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That didn't happen. They are doing this on immigration. They are in the teens in immigration in the polling and they are sort of like, yes, we're not doing anything on that. And then the midterm ads write themselves because basically what they've done is a, we're not going to pay attention to the things you care about even though people are saying, these are the things we care about and they still ignore them. And there is -- today they are pushing this $500 billion for climate change issues while people are actually talking about the high price of gas and groceries. And then they have this grab bag of policies, and it's like if your mom gave you $20 and said go to the store and get some groceries for the family and you go and you get two six packs of beer and some magazines, you come home and say, no, the family is still hungry. And what the deputy press secretary said today was that we have no specifics on that. And they won't. And this is a story that's not going to go away like in Afghanistan. It's not on the front pages, but it's still on people's minds. Winter is just beginning. And so you got a long way ahead. Granholm just said, 54 percent increase for your heating oil costs. You think that's not going to reverberate through the whole country? And also it takes a while for supply and demand to work itself out on energy issues and they are not doing anything to increase supply except for asking OPEC to help. That's a bad position to be in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Two six packs and a couple of magazines. That's my Thanksgiving. It's affordable. You know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But you'll still be hungry.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And your family is upset.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Global warming might bail them out with energy shortages.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Everything is racist according to the Biden administration. Even roads. That's next on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: The Biden administration is laser focused on the issues affecting every day Americans like how roads are racist. Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg says the new infrastructure bill will address that.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.utterance: Can you give us the construct of how you will deconstruct the racism that was built into the roadways that you talked to theGrio earlier?

utterances.speaker: PETE BUTTIGIEG, TRANSPORTATION SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: I'm still surprised that some people were surprised when I pointed to the fact that if a highway was built for the purpose of dividing a white and a black neighborhood, or if an underpass was constructed such that a bus carrying mostly black and Puerto Rican kids to a beach -- or that would have been -- in New York was designed too low for it to pass by, but that obviously reflects racism that went into those design choices.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Trees can apparently be racist. Vice President Kamala Harris asking NASA about it.

utterances.speaker: KAMAL HARRIS, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: Can you measure trees, as part of the data that you're referring to, and it's an E.J., it's environmental justice but you can also track by race, there are averages in terms of the number of trees in the neighborhood where people live.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Racist! Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I've got to say Mayor Pete looks great. Clearly he's lost the baby weight. This is the problem with the "everything is racist prism" because you can apply it to everything and it's very seductive because it makes the user seem educated and clever when it's merely kind of repeating something that you already heard. He just heard those stories so he repeats it and it comes out as, wow, this is really interesting, but it's actually not an original thought, but it's an acceptable thought at cocktail parties. The problem with this, how does his policy or the policy based on this affect the actual outcome?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Like, where are you going to change the bridges or the streets? What if the changes are actually really good for everybody? Like what if the improvements on this racist, you know, bridge actually is beneficial? Why did you have to bring this up? But if you don't have a specific solution for this, but you brought it up anyway, then it's a pretty obvious virtue signal to appear thoughtful and progressive and woke, but I just -- I'm interested to see when this was all done, where they are going to point to and go, see, this was the bridge I was talking about.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Cross Bronx Expressway. I could point to it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So what are you going to do with it?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The question is, you don't use this money for social engineering. I mean, that's the problem. That's what's disappointing to me. Eisenhower's interstate system was the grandest, greatest, public works project there was since the Erie Canal. It opened up America for everybody. It benefitted everybody. Rich people, poor people, black people, white people, Asian people, Hispanic people. Everybody benefited. If we start with Pete Buttigieg leading the way to point at these projects like to change the bridge over the Cross Bronx Expressway which works fine now, people have adjusted, instead of building new bridges or repairing the bridges that exist and tunnels and roadways and making Wi-Fi available for everybody. And it's going to be in the hands of the same racially oriented politicians that we used to call poverty pimps when I was the lawyer for the Young Lords. Poverty pimps. They work. They jockey these programs. They find out what's happening. If you make this a social program, a social welfare program, which is what "Build Back Better" is supposed to be, but if you make infrastructure, social welfare, what you're going to get is nothing. At the end of the line you're going to have that money squandered.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: I have a theory about why Buttigieg would be talking about this now, but it's to Greg's point. Any time you, like talk about racism and call someone or a group of people racist you're trying to get them scared and to back off and to kind of butt out. And to Dana, I wonder -- to Geraldo's point, it's because they want power and control over that money and they don't want anybody to ask any questions. It's not going to get built on, taking down overpasses. It's going to get built on things that aren't roads, bridges and actual infrastructure.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, also it says its a billion dollars to remedy, so what's the remedy, right? And that could also be said about the tree issue and tree equity. I understand what you're saying, like more trees in a place is a good thing. And if you look at a place like, I believe its Greenville, South Carolina. Twenty-five years ago there was a big push to put trees down the main street and there was a big controversy. It was going to cost too much money. Now, it's lovely because the trees are built -- the trees have grown up. It's shady. It's a beautiful street to shop along. It benefits everyone. And I think what the voters were saying last Tuesday is that we can support things that support everybody but we don't want to be put in these different categories. We might need to right some wrongs in the past, but then again, the remedy, as they say here, is going to actually benefit everyone because we don't have that society like we used to have.

utterances.speaker: MCDOEWLL
utterances.utterance: Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I did a deep dive on this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No you didn't.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Deep even for me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And what I found out that, yes, race was a factor in some of the design of the interstate highway system, granted. But class was a much bigger factor. Poor white and black neighborhoods were carved up by this highway system because it's much easier to seize a poor neighborhood through eminent domain. You put the artery into the downtown shopping district and the artery out to the suburbs for the commuters and that's how it's done. They went into German, Italian, Jewish neighborhoods, all white people, and they just carved them out. How many times have you heard the phrase "this poor white neighborhood" on the wrong side of the tracks? It's always a wrong side of the tracks. It is not black, it's not white. It's about rich and poor. And that's how they did this. So, just because we have to fix a part of the system doesn't mean the system was racist. It just means some of it was designed by idiots. Most of the problems we have in this country is because of idiots, not because of racists. And what the idiots are doing in the Biden administration is they're saying we're going to start destroying highways and we're going to replace these highways with mass transit. We don't want mass transit. Mass transit has been on the decline for the last 15 years. We just came out of a pandemic where people are leaving cities. People are working remotely. The last thing we need are more trains and subways and buses. So they are just going to jam this down our throat. And what's going to happen, the Big Dig. Remember Boston? They tried to rip up their whole highway system and it took 25 years and the cost was five times as bad, and it just created more drama and more, I don't know, congestion, which creates more emissions. So you're going to now see a boondoggle ala the Big Dig in every single city and in every single place where this Build Back Better money is going to go and you're just going to look back and say, Jesse Watters was right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We do that all the time.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You came right to my mind. Always got that, damn, that Jesse was right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Always right.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Always looking for the opportunity to use word the boondoggle.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Boondoggle. I love -- billion dollar boondoggle.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Say it with Buttigieg.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's his.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: It's actually --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He looks great by the way.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, he really does.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He really has lost a lot of baby weight.

utterances.speaker: GUTELD
utterances.utterance: You know, what a bounce back. Usually it takes months, but you know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think he was on the treadmill.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He got the one treadmill they couldn't get.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The one peloton.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: I was about to make a joke, and I am editing myself because it would get me in so much trouble, Dana Perino. Ahead on "The Five," Democrats not learning their lesson. They can't stop smearing parents.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Ignore those school board moms at your peril. Like it or lump it, Democrats and the media still not getting the message over why they got their butts kicked in Virginia. Republican Senator Rick Scott calling out CNN over why parents revolted in the old dominion.

utterances.speaker: BRIANNA KEILAR, CNN HOST
utterances.utterance: It's not in the curriculum in Virginia. Just to be --

utterances.speaker: SEN. RICK SCOTT (R-FL)
utterances.utterance: Brianna (inaudible) here. Let me just read you a few things.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.utterance: Just to --

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.utterance: In 2015, look, Terry McAuliffe was governor. The Virginia Department of Education promoting incorporating a critical race theory lens in education. You can still find it on the Department of Education's website. Still there. In February of 2019 --

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.utterance: It's not -- it's not part of the --

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.utterance: -- a superintendent memo from the Virginia Department of Education promoting critical race theory --

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.utterance: Senator, it's not --

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.utterance: -- and the idea of white fragility. I hope Democrats continue to say it's not happening because parents are dumb. They can see it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: They look so unhappy on CNN.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, they are because they are.

utterances.speaker: RIUVERA
utterances.utterance: And yet DNC Chair Jamie Harrison still doubling down on the notion that racism was behind the Republican victories.

utterances.speaker: JAMIE HARRISON, DNC CHAIRMAN
utterances.utterance: They understand that the only (inaudible) power for them is to make the American people scared. To come up with all of the dog whistles and the boogeymen and all of that. Democrats have to call out the lies and we have to be bold and calling them out and we've got to make sure that we paint the contract. Let people know what we have done for them.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And why I think he's right about that, Democrats if they have achievements should be promoting their achievements, Dagen, but as a resident of -- as someone who hails from the old dominion, don't you think race is relevant for children growing up in Virginia because Virginia was like the heart and soul of the slave economy.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: History is taught. History should be taught. That's not what critical race theory is about and it's not the problem that parents and Virginians had when they went to the polls and elected a Republican governor and a Republican lieutenant governor or the first black woman ever elected to statewide office, and a Republican attorney general. I mean, I could sit here for days and go over what is being taught in the Virginia schools that they take issue with. It's derived from say, the ideas in Albemarle County, from Ibram Kendi, author of "How to Be an Anti- Racist," children being taught words like cisgender, white privilege, non- Christian folks with an X. And like issues of gender, race, sexuality, things that parent feel like should be up to them. I digress. But I love watching Brianna Keilar or whatever her name is, belching up what her liberal overlords have told her to regurgitate. It's got to burn. I love how they will take parents are delusional wackos and then Trump and Russia collusion and they say something real is made up and then say something made up is real. That's the world in which they live. It is -- they are evangelists of left wing moronicy.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But you can't ignore, race matters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, the race does matter and that's what the parents were saying. We don't like being taught reverse racism. We don't our students, our children being called born racist in elementary school. I want to talk about Brianna.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't like to do this because I don't like to ever mention these people by name. I feel like I want to be loved and I don't ever want to see these people at bars and have their wives or their husbands throw haymakers at me.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: We love you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't like to punch down like Gutfeld. I don't want to, you know, elevate the competition, but I think --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can only punch up at my height.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think we need to address Brianna. Maybe she's nice. Maybe we get along if we met each other, but she is on a network that says facts first, and she at this point doesn't know that CRT is embedded in the curriculum of the Virginia school system? At this point she doesn't know this? The story has been percolating since April and she doesn't know that. I mean, does she now also think the dossier was real? Does she think the Youngkin supporters were the ones with the tiki torches? Does she think, Geraldo --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- that those two brothers actually did knock around Jussie Smollett that night in Chicago? Because I don't know if her producers are not giving her the right information. If I were Brianna, I would blame the producers too. That's what I do. But this is why our show's so much better than that show. So many reasons, here's one. We get these research packets in the morning and they have facts in the packets, Brianna. And they also have articles from the left and the right so you know what the left is saying about an issue, you know what the right saying about an issue, you know what the media is saying about an issue. And then we as hosts do our own research and we look for the truth and then we formulate our opinions based on that truth. So, there's truth out there. It's on the internet. She could look that up anywhere she wants. And if I ever make a mistake on the air, I will go about and correct it. And that's a few times I've been challenged and then in the commercial break I say, maybe I'm wrong here, nope not wrong. And then the other person has to correct the record. For instance, the other day, I said erroneously that the staff was not trendy. And I immediately corrected the record and I think Brianna should do the same.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The staff was not trending?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes -- trendy.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Oh, trendy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I gave them my shirt.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, they're so trendy now.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Doesn't it remind you -- Dana, isn't it parallel to the old teaching sex ed to third graders and fourth graders. I mean parents are edgy generally speaking.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't remember that.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, you're younger.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't remember that but it could be.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You don't remember? They don't want like graphics, sex --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It could be. We'll check it out at the commercial break and figure --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: -- this is the boys --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think a lot of this also has to do with many people who are commenting about this and saying it has nothing to do with these schools. They don't have school-age children. And if you look at the exit polls in Virginia, parents of school-aged children K-12 went for Youngkin by a huge margin. And so, they have taken on parents and they've made them mad. And -- but the parents were not just mad about the CRT thing. They're mad that the schools were closed for so long, that there was a major loss of learning, that they don't even have the opportunity to have gifted and talented programs and advanced math. When Youngkin says I will make sure that every high school has advanced math and he gets applause, that's when you know parents are really paying attention. And they're making a mistake not doing the same.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Do you really believe in your heart of hearts, Greg, that it isn't a signal -- Dana talks of virtue signaling. Isn't there race signaling also? When you look at some of the rural counties in Virginia that went for Youngkin by 80 percent, 80 to 20, isn't there something about -- isn't race relevant to that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not in this --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Weren't some white suburban --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wait, what?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not in this era. Maybe if that question was 50 years ago --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: He's calling my family a bunch of bigots, so let's just be clear.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. But you know, but there is -- there is a lot of this race- baiting but it's all in reverse. For example, calling this history when in -- the title of it, it says theory.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes. Good point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's Critical Race Theory. It is not history. That's why it's not -- sex education is not a parallel analogy because that's education. This is merely theory. The woke demands that you give them proof. And you saw what happened with Brianna. She's not woke, she just dim.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You guys have been so cruel --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, she had -- no, you have to point this out. She asked for proof. And when he gave her proof, she didn't want to hear it because she knew she was in the wrong so she just put that scowl on. People like Chris Rufo and this show -- remember, this show, when we first started doing this topic, we had the examples in the -- in our copy that said this is where CRT is taught and this is what CRT is. The irony and the best part about this is when you hear proponents of CRT try to define it, and you hear critics try to define it, the definition is entirely the same. That's what kills me. They're not disagreeing. Identify children by their race within a country riven with systemic racism with the conclusion that White is the oppressor, right, and Black is the victim. If you say that, the proponents will go, that's pretty good. You got it. And the critics will go, you're absolutely right. That's exactly what they're saying. So, they're in agreement here. That's the funniest part about this. And it is dead because the parents finally woke up to this and found out that this was dangerous. Children are not equipped at that age to discuss this topic especially when adults can't talk about it either.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I think the tragedy is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Don't call people racist.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: -- Black people are Democrats, White people are Republicans in the working class, and the country is permanently divided by race. I think it's tragic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Who fought to end slavery, Democrats or was it the Republicans? I can't remember.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It was the north.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: And the people where I grew up voted on pocketbook issues. They voted on job creation. They voted on charter schools.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And black -- and Black and White was irrelevant? Come on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's not -- you're talking -- that's not an answer.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Kamala Harris escaping her problem here at home by jetting off to Paris. I love Paris.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You should --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Great band. Vice President Kamala Harris leaving the country and all her troubles behind, jetting off to Paris which is in France, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: On a diplomatic trip that critic say is an attempt at raising her international profile while her poll numbers hit rock bottom. Kamala's favorability falling to a comically bad 28% which is a historic low for any modern vice president. So, Dana, this reminds me of like, you know, when certain performers aren't doing well in America, they've suddenly become big in Japan or David Hasselhoff is big in Germany. So, she's like, oh -- she comes out, they love me in Denmark.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, they have the people that they hired to do like an image makeover.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.utterance: And remember the child actors that they hired --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's a great idea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Send her to space.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I wish that I could be her --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tell -- what piece of advice? What piece of advice?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: -- to for instance, get energized, go to the border. Do the hard thing. You know --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I've given that advice.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Go to the -- go to infrastructure, go to the bridge where there's some -- the concrete's falling on your head. Show why things are needed. Have engagement. You know, charisma. You can do this. I mean, she got to --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You're asking for things that are not possible.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: No, but -- she was attorney general, she was the senator, she's a real person who forgot who she was when they put her in this job. And then -- and the more her poll shrunk, the more she shrunk. And the less -- now, they're pushing her aside.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I would say, come on, Kamala.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Wake up. Get in there. You could do this. She is being canceled by the right-wing woke mob.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, Geraldo, she is being canceled by the West Wing. It's the West Wing. They are --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, maybe both. Maybe both.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, that was funny. Dagen, it's kind of funny since vice president is a really easy job, right? Anybody can do it.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Right. With the help of child actors.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's something.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Right. The right is really making her life miserable, right? So, there was a headline on ABC.com. It said, going on a fence-mending trip. This is the same woman who was so unnatural and uncomfortable they had to hire actors to interact with her to Dana's point. And the next line was she's going on a charm offensive. That's like coming to me for diction lessons. But I guess if they send her to Germany, the Germans don't laugh so I suppose the ha, ha, ha would seem normal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, Jesse, you brought this point up, and I want to bring it back to you. She's got to be feeling some heat from Mayor Pete, you know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. She sure does.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He could be replacing her.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He sure could. And I do -- I do want to --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I want to actually go back to what Dana said. That was just great. Geraldo said that the right-wing is canceling Kamala, and you said the West Wing was. That was really good. That was really good, Dana. That was really, really good. I think that deserves some applause. The context here is very key, Greg. So, you remember when the Europeans wanted to seize the Libyan oil field so they begged Obama and Biden can you help us topple Gaddafi?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, then they're like yes, let's lead from behind. They go topple Gaddafi. It turns into a failed state, creates a migrant crisis that the Europeans can't solve, and the Europeans are like, all right, who else knows how to trigger a migrant crisis and not solve it? Kamala Harris, let's get over here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She's amazing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. All right, "THE FASTEST" is up next.

utterances.utterance: Welcome back. It's time for "THE FASTEST." Fist up, a really bizarre admission from one in six Americans who say they don't use the dishwasher for washing dishes. What about you? Do you do dishes?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what -- you know what, this made me sad. It made me think that there are just fewer households with fewer families, right? It reflects the decline of the dining family. You don't do dishes when it's just dinner for one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow. Way to bring the mood down.

utterances.utterance: Fear not.

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I wanted to say how I used my dishwasher but then I thought maybe I should just shut up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Maybe -- it sounds like you might.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Now I'm really curious.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.utterance: Wow. I can just picture it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But Dagen, when I first moved here, I would notice like how small the apartments are and I looked a couple of places where people would put their shoes in the oven.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Yes, the oven is for storage, the dishwasher, if you're lucky to have one in New York City, is for doing dishes or washing small pets and animals.

utterances.utterance: You can do that?

utterances.utterance: No, I just made that up.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

That's my regret.

utterances.utterance: All right, here is tonight's edition of Geraldo's Geraldo News with Geraldo. I was honored to speak at the annual dinner of one of Cleveland's most venerated charities for the last 60 years. The Bluecoats have provided assistance to the families of cops, firefighters, and other safety officers who have fallen or become permanently disabled in the line of duty. Our outgoing Cleveland Police Chief Calvin Williams spoke about how Bluecoats have come to the aid of these families. Erica and I met Chief Sheila Mason, the first black and first woman to serve as police chief of Woodmere, one of our exclusive local communities. My message was simple. We need to embrace cops because they need us as much as we need them. The Bluecoats seemed to like my remarks. A good time was had by all.

utterances.utterance: Very nice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
